title: Question 33

children: This question has been updated as a result of postpublication analysis and/or new data that are relevant to the question.

A 33-year-old woman is evaluated during a preconception counseling visit. She is nulliparous. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is asymptomatic, without medical problems. She received her measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine during childhood and an influenza vaccine during the most recent influenza season. She received the tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine 6 years ago and recently completed the hepatitis B vaccine series. She is unsure whether she had chickenpox. She is sexually active with her husband only. Her last Pap smear was obtained 1 year ago and was normal; human papillomavirus testing was negative. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin.
A pregnancy test result is negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Obtain nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia

children: All women considering pregnancy should be assessed for immunity to varicella and rubella.
If an already pregnant woman is not immune to either varicella or rubella, these vaccines should be administered after delivery and before hospital discharge.
The most appropriate management is to obtain a varicella antibody titer (

). All women considering pregnancy should be assessed for immunity to varicella and rubella. This patient reports receiving the measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine during childhood but is unsure whether she had varicella (chickenpox). She should have a varicella antibody titer test. If she is not immune to varicella, she should receive the varicella vaccine and be instructed to wait 4 weeks before attempting to conceive. If an already pregnant woman is not immune to either varicella or rubella, these vaccines should be administered after delivery but before hospital discharge. Immunizations to be avoided during pregnancy include live vaccines (varicella, rubella, measles, mumps, live attenuated influenza, live attenuated herpes zoster) and human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine.
All pregnant women should receive a tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine (

) between 27 weeks' and 36 weeks' gestation with each pregnancy, helping to ensure immunity to the child upon birth. Administering Tdap during pregnancy is recommended regardless of when a patient received her last tetanus vaccination. This patient is currently not pregnant and should not receive the Tdap vaccine at this visit because she is otherwise current with this vaccination.
A nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia (

) is not indicated for this patient. Chlamydia screening of all sexually active women younger than 25 years is recommended. Women aged 25 years or older should be screened if they have sexually transmitted infection (STI) risk factors, such as new or multiple sex partners, sex partners who have multiple other partners, no or inconsistent condom use (outside a monogamous partnership), previous STI, current STI, or exchanging sex for money or drugs. This patient is not high risk, and although screening for STIs is considered routine during pregnancy, it is not necessary during preconception care.
A Pap smear is not indicated (

). The patient's last Pap smear was obtained 1 year ago and was normal; HPV testing was negative. Women aged 30 to 39 years who have a normal Pap smear and a negative HPV test result do not require another Pap smear for 5 years.

objective.__html: Provide preconception care for an average-risk woman.

references: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. ACOG committee opinion no. 762 summary: prepregnancy counseling. Obstet Gynecol. 2019;133:228-30.
